com.brianmearns.crafter

Class MapBuilder<K,V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.brianmearns.crafter.MapBuilder<K,V>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    BuilderInterface<java.util.Map<K,V>>, com.google.common.base.Supplier<java.util.Map<K,V>>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    MapBuilder.DefaultMapBuilder, MapBuilder.NeverMapBuilder

    public abstract class MapBuilder<K,V>
extends java.lang.Object
implements BuilderInterface<java.util.Map<K,V>>
    A BuilderInterface of map objects.

    Map elements are put into the builder as a key and its value. Putting the same key again will effectively replace previous value associated with that key.

      • create

        @Nonnull
public static <K,V> MapBuilder<K,V> create()
        Create a new builder instance which will build Map instances.
        Type Parameters:
        K - The type for the keys that will be put into the built maps.
        V - The type for the value that will be put into the built maps.
        Returns:
        The newly constructed MapBuilder.

      • create

        @Nonnull
public static <K,V> MapBuilder<K,V> create(@Nonnull
                                   java.lang.Class<K> keyCls,
                                   @Nonnull
                                   java.lang.Class<V> valueCls)
        Create a new builder instance which will build Map instances.

        This is an alternative convenience interface over create() with no args. Instead of specifying type parameters on the method call, you can just pass in the classes you want to use and the compiler will determine the correct type parameters automatically.

        Type Parameters:
        K - The type for the keys that will be put into the built maps.
        V - The type for the value that will be put into the built maps.
        Parameters:
        keyCls - The class of keys that will be put into the build maps.
        valueCls - The class of values that will be put into the build maps.
        Returns:
        The newly constructed MapBuilder.

      • put

                  K key,
                  @Nullable

        Put the given value in the builder's map.

      • put

        public MapBuilder<K,V> put(@Nullable
                  K key,
                  @Nonnull
                  BuilderInterface<? extends V> value)
        Put a value in the builder's map, represented by a BuilderInterface of that value.

        Note that the given builder is not invoked to build the value right away, it is invoked once for each call to get().

        Parameters:
        key - The key at which to put the value.
        value - The value to put at the given key.
        Returns:
        This builder instance itself, for chaining convenience.

      • maybePut

        public MapBuilder<K,V> maybePut(@Nullable
                       K key,
                       @Nullable
                       V value,
                       boolean put)
        Place the given key-value pair in the builder, if and only if the given boolean is true. Otherwise has no effect on the state of the builder.
        Parameters:
        key - The key at which to put the value.
        value - The value to put at the given key.
        put - Whether or not to actually update the builder.
        Returns:
        This builder instance itself, for chaining convenience.

      • maybePut

        public MapBuilder<K,V> maybePut(@Nullable
                       K key,
                       @Nonnull
                       BuilderInterface<? extends V> value,
                       boolean put)
        Place the given key-value pair in the builder, if and only if the given boolean is true. Otherwise has no effect on the state of the builder.
        Parameters:
        key - The key at which to put the value.
        value - Builder of the value to put at the given key.
        put - Whether or not to actually update the builder.
        Returns:
        This builder instance itself, for chaining convenience.

      • apply

        public abstract MapBuilder<K,V> apply(com.google.common.base.Function<MapBuilder<K,V>,java.lang.Void> function)
        Apply the given function to this object, and return this object again.

        This is simply a way to add some arbitrary code in the middle of a chain of method invocations. You could use the Function to perform some complex logic to configure the builder, for instance.

        The return value of the function is ignored, but for safety and clarity, it should be a void return.

        Parameters:
        function - The Function to be invoked on this object.
        Returns:
        This MapBuilder itself, for chaining convenience.
